item.title: Your opinion of the packages COGugaison and CARTElette
item.description: This survey aims to better know the users of the two R packages COGugaison and CARTElette, which make possible to manage the evolution of administrative divisions over time in France, in databases and map layers. Thank you very much for your participation which will contribute to the improvement of these packages!

item.title: First post full of love :blue_heart: thanks to emojifont package
item.description:
A first article to celebrate the creation of this blog thanks to Hugo and blogdown. I can now create posts (in French and / or English) with one click from R.

It is also an opportunity to share with you my discovery of the emojifont package which allows to add small images to our ggplots. Thank you @guangchuangyu!

#install.packages("emojifont")
library(emojifont)
## Warning: le package 'emojifont' a Ã©tÃ© compilÃ© avec la version R 3.3.3
library(ggplot2)
emoji('blue_heart')
## [1] "<f0><U+009F><U+0092><U+0099>"
t= seq(-1, 1, length=50)
x=cos(t)*sin(t)*log(abs(t))
y=sqrt(abs(t))*cos(t)
#windows()
ggplot() + geom_emoji('blue_heart', x=x, y=y, size=10, color="#00BCF2")

item.title: R Packages
item.description: COGugaison is an R package for manipulating french spatial databases produced at different dates The administrative divisions of France (communes â€“ counties â€“ regions, departmentsâ€¦) change over time. Every year, some french territories change their codes, or names, merge or divide. The COGugaison R package is based on the french official geographic code (COG) produced each year by the french National Institute of Statistics and Economic Studies (Insee). It has the objective of manipulating spatial databases produced at different dates by providing the list of existing towns and their history since fifty years and useful functions for transforming databases into geographic codes of other years.

item.title: Ã€ propos
item.description: hello ! My name is Kim, i’m a female statistician and I love doing R when I’m lonely at home. The objective of this blog is to share with you my R discoveries when I have time (some periods are more effective than others) and talk about developers or reseachers works and there super cool packages that I find interesting. I also love open data so I may also indicate some cool data to manipulate.
